name: Pempek Kapal Selam
description: The most iconic type of Pempek from Palembang. Made from fish and tapioca dough, shaped large and filled with a whole egg inside. It is boiled, then fried, and served with cuko — a sweet, sour, and spicy vinegar-based sauce. Rich, savory, and deeply satisfying.
history: Pempek Kapal Selam was created as a variation of traditional Pempek. Its name 'submarine' comes from the large shape and the egg hidden inside, resembling the contents of a submarine. Today, it is considered the signature dish of Palembang cuisine.

name: Mie Celor
description: Palembang-style fish ball soup. Small fish balls in a clear broth with mushrooms, glass noodles, and jicama. Light but full of flavor.
history: The word “tekwan” is believed to come from Hokkien Chinese “tio kwan,” meaning “meet and chat.” It was a dish served in gatherings, showing Chinese influence in Palembang cuisine.

name: Laksan
description: Thick oval fish cakes served in spicy coconut milk gravy. Rich, creamy, and slightly spicy – like a heavier version of burgo.
history: Laksan is usually served during Eid and big family events in Palembang. It’s considered a festive dish, symbolizing warmth and togetherness.

name: Pindang Patin
description: Palembang’s most loved dishes. It’s a sour and spicy fish soup made with patin (catfish), pineapple, lemongrass, chili, and other spices. The broth is light but packed with flavor – fresh, tangy, and a little hot, perfect with a plate of warm rice. The catfish is tender and soaks up all the seasoning, making every bite super tasty.
history: Pindang has been around since the days of the Palembang Sultanate. Locals who lived along the Musi River had easy access to freshwater fish, so they developed a cooking style that could keep the fish fresh and flavorful. Instead of frying or grilling, they boiled it with lots of spices, creating a sour-spicy soup that could last longer.

name: Celimpungan
description: Small round fish dumplings cooked in yellow coconut milk soup with turmeric and spices. Creamy, fragrant, and very filling.
history: The name comes from the word celimpung (rolling around in water). It’s a traditional comfort food, often cooked for family meals or gatherings.

name: Pempek
description: The superstar of Palembang food! Fish mixed with tapioca flour, chewy texture, and always eaten with cuko – a dark sweet-spicy sauce. Types include lenjer (long stick), kapal selam (with egg inside), adaan (fried balls), and kulit (fish skin).
history: Pempek has been around since the 16th century. People by the Musi River wanted a new way to enjoy fish, so they mixed it with sago. The name comes from “apek,” an old Chinese man who first sold it. People calling “pek..pek” turned into “pempek.”

name: Kemplang
description: Kemplang is a crunchy grilled fish cracker, made from fish and tapioca, then roasted until crispy. Usually eaten as a snack or side dish with sambal.
history: Kemplang has been a traditional snack for generations in Palembang, created as a way to preserve fish. Unlike regular fried crackers, locals preferred grilling, which made it lighter and gave a smoky flavor.

name: Tekwan
description: Palembang-style fish ball soup. Small fish balls in a clear broth with mushrooms, glass noodles, and jicama. Light but full of flavor.
history: The word “tekwan” is believed to come from Hokkien Chinese “tio kwan,” meaning “meet and chat.” It was a dish served in gatherings, showing Chinese influence in Palembang cuisine.

name: Es Kacang Merah
description: A refreshing dessert made of red beans served with shaved ice, syrup, and condensed milk. Sweet, cold, and perfect for hot Palembang weather.
history: This dessert came from Chinese influence, where sweet beans were commonly used in snacks. Palembang locals turned it into an iced treat to fight the tropical heat.

name: Kue 8 Jam
description: As the name says, it literally takes eight hours to cook! Steamed with eggs, sugar, and condensed milk, making it sweet, dense, and rich. Special for big celebrations like weddings.
history: Kue 8 Jam has been around since the Palembang Sultanate era. It was once served only at weddings and big ceremonies because it was expensive and took hours to make, making it a symbol of luxury. Today, it’s a Palembang icon that visitors love to try.

name: Kue Gandus
description: A soft steamed rice flour cake topped with spiced minced meat, fried shallots, and celery. The texture is smooth and silky, but the topping gives a savory punch.
history: Kue Gandus shows the mix of Malay and Chinese culinary influences in Palembang. Originally made for family gatherings and religious ceremonies, it became a favorite savory snack for everyday tea time.

name: Pempek Lenggang
description: A special version of pempek – grilled fish cake mixed with beaten eggs, usually served with cucumber and cuko. Smoky, soft, and savory.
history: Pempek Lenggang started as a way to use leftover pempek dough. Locals mixed it with egg and grilled it, creating a new favorite that’s still enjoyed today.

name: Martabak Kari
description: A refreshing dessert made of red beans served with shaved ice, syrup, and condensed milk. Sweet, cold, and perfect for hot Palembang weather.
history: This dessert came from Chinese influence, where sweet beans were commonly used in snacks. Palembang locals turned it into an iced treat to fight the tropical heat.
